summary: Apple device management company, Jamf (NASDAQ:JAMF) reported Q1 CY2025 results exceeding the market’s revenue expectations . Sales up 10.2% year on year to $167.6 million . Guidance for next quarter's revenue was better than expected at $168.5 million at the midpoint, 1.5% above estimates .  Jamf provides software for companies to manage Apple devices such as Macs, iPads, and iPhones . Over the last three years, Jamf grew its sales at a 17.7% compounded annual growth rate . Company management is currently guiding for a 10.1% year-on-year increase in sales next quarter .  Sell-side analysts expect revenue to grow 7.3% over the next 12 months, a deceleration versus the last three years . This projection doesn't excite us and implies its products and services will face some demand challenges . The company is already riding the automation wave and looking to catch the generative AI next .  Jamf’s billings came in at $161.3 million in Q1 . Over the last four quarters, its growth was underwhelming as it averaged 8.9% year-on-year increases . Increasing competition is causing challenges in acquiring/retaining customers .  Jamf's revenue guidance for next quarter exceeded Wall Street’s estimates . The stock remained flat at $11.36 immediately following the results . We think that the latest quarter is just one piece of the longer-term business quality puzzle .

US central bank voted to hold base rates at 4.25pc to 4.5pc yesterday . Jerome Powell warned the White House’s trade policies had created ‘a great deal of uncertainty’ The hawkish comments sent US stocks down slightly, before rebounding .  White House has pointed to cuts by other central banks as evidence the Fed should reduce rates . Bank of England will announce its decision on UK rates on Thursday, in a move which could create more tension for the Fed .  The Fed has sat on its hands for three straight meetings, after a trio of cuts late last year . Mr Powell said on Wednesday it was possible to foresee a case in which monetary policy might need to be eased .  Mr Trump has been impatient for Fed action to offset a short-term tariff hit to US growth . He is likely to blame the Fed rather than tariffs for mid-year economic woes . American companies and consumers have raced to stockpile imported goods ahead of tariffs .  The S&P 500 closed up 0.4pc, the Nasdaq 0.3pc and the S.P 500 0.7pc . US stocks helped earlier today on hopes that the US would cut back on trade hostilities with China . But Donald Trump said he would not reduce his 145pc tariffs on Chinese goods as a condition, pushed by China, for negotiations .  Jerome Powell has said that he has never asked for a meeting with any US president . The Fed chairman said that there was 'never a reason' for him to ask for such a meeting . The risks of higher unemployment and higher inflation have left the Fed with almost no good short-term options, an analyst said .  Jerome Powell has rejected criticism that the US Fed has taken on topics like climate change that are outside its mandate to address inflation and employment . The Fed chairman said: “We’ve done really very little on climate. We have very, very narrow things - we did one guidance for the banks and we did a one-time climate stress analysis. And that’s it... It's a real danger for us to try and take on a mandate like that that has very very narrow ones .  Jerome Powell said the US economy is still in a good place, despite all the uncertainty . He said the right thing for the Fed is to wait for more clarity as a result of the trade war . Mr Powell said Donald Trump’s demands for rate cuts “doesn’t affect doing our job at all”  Jerome Powell said there is too much uncertainty over Donald Trump's tariffs to know if rate cuts will take place this year . The head of the US Fed has said that the central bank is in no rush to change interest rates .  US Fed chairman Jerome Powell said there is a great deal of uncertainty about where tariffs are going to settle out and what will be the implications for the economy, for growth and for employment . He said: “For the time being, we are well positioned to wait for greater clarity before considering any adjustments to our policy stance’  Jerome Powell has warned over the economic damage of Donald Trump’s trade war . The Fed chairman has said that US growth figures have been “complicated’ by an “unusual swing” caused by companies stockpiling goods ahead of the tariffs . He said the effects on inflation could be short-lived, reflecting a one-time shift in the price level .  Mr Trump is preparing for his first major diplomatic trip next week that includes a three-country Middle East tour . The Biden administration imposed strict controls on exports of American AI chips to the Middle East over fears the prized semiconductors could be diverted to China .  The S&P 500 and Nasdaq remain down overall today, while the Dow Jones is up . US Treasury yields were little changed, while traders continued to eye a US interest rate hike . US stock markets reacted to the announcement by sending shares slightly higher .  Isaac Stell, investment manager at Wealth Club, said the Fed is in a holding pattern . Jerome Powell is already under intense scrutiny and likely to be on the receiving end of another social media tirade .  Donald Trump has said he will not cut tariffs on China as a way of encouraging negotiations with Beijing . In a meeting with reporters, he said ‘no’ when asked if he is open to reducing his 145pc duties on Chinese imports .  Apple indicated it was looking at including integrating AI search engines with its Safari browser . Suggestion hit the tech-heavy Nasdaq, which is down 0.2pc . But Dow Jones is up 0.7pc and the S&P 500 is up . European markets closed lower after data showed a higher-than-expected decline in eurozone retail sales .  Investors were also worried about the health of European pharmaceutical profits after the US drug regulator appointed a critic, Vinay Prasad, as its top vaccine official . Lale Akoner, an analyst at eToro, said the Fed's credibility is central to its decision-making framework .  The stock market index had been on a winning streak for more than two weeks - having reached its longest-ever run of consecutive gains on Friday . But fortunes reversed today with it losing 0.4pc, to close at 8,559.33 . It signals an end to the period of recovery for the index .  Traders in cautious mood ahead of important monetary policy decisions . US’s Federal Reserve expected to keep interest rates unchanged at 7pm tonight . This would mean the central bank does not bow to pressure from Mr Trump . Bank of England widely expected to cut interest rates by 0.25 percentage points tomorrow .  European Union is accelerating free trade talks with Asia following hefty tariffs by Donald Trump . The EU trade commissioner said negotiations with Washington remained a priority but such talks will not come “at any cost” Maros Sefcovic said the price hikes will affect vehicles built after May 2 .  Mexico will fight to maintain its free trade agreement with the US and Canada . The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement came into force in 2020 . The agreement is up for review in 2026 .  Apple suggested it was looking at changing the search feature built into its Safari browser . The S&P 500 is flat, while the Nasdaq is down 0.3pc . The Dow Jones Industrial Average remains up 0.5pc .  Comments appear to signal a shift in position after Sir Keir’s administration spent months rejecting idea . US treasury secretary Scott Bessent said talks with China on Saturday will be the first between the two nations .  JD Vance said relations between the US and Europe “got a bit off track” after the US vice president ruffled feathers with a scathing address on free speech earlier this year . He added that it was “time for China to graduate from developing country status”  The S&P 500 is up 0.5pc, while the Nasdaq and Dow Jones are up . US Treasury secretary Scott Bessent and trade negotiator Jamieson Greer are set for talks on Saturday with Chinese officials . Analysts said the market was encouraged by the talks after earlier tit-for-tat measures .  JD Vance said the trade relations with Europe could improve if members of the bloc lifted restrictions on US products . The vice president zoned in on restrictions around agricultural products, defence equipment and technology as key examples .  Jonathan Heath, the central bank’s deputy governor, said the monetary authority would likely continue lowering the rate . He added that all scenarios considered by the bank expected a slowdown in Mexico's economy, as well as in the US .  Wall Street’s main stock indexes were up in early trading amid optimism about a US-China trade meeting in Switzerland at the weekend . The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.4pc to 40,994.34 while the benchmark S&P 500 gained 0.3pc . The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2pc to 17,724.56 .  HSBC has launched a new loan product to American companies struggling to cover the costs that have risen from Donald Trump’s tariff war . The bank said its TradePay platform was being extended to directly cover the cost of tariff payments . FTSE 100 lender said this would allow importers to meet the increased expenses caused by shipping products into the US .  HSBC chairman Mark Tucker said last week that world trade was facing a “period of deep and profound change” The bank said it was committed to supporting global businesses as a strategic partner and innovative problem solver, helping our clients navigate the complexities of global trade .  Liberal Democrat leader urged Sir Keir Starmer to stand up to Mr Trump on behalf of the industry . Mr Starmer said: 'If he picks a fight with James Bond, Bridget Jones and Paddington Bear, he will lose'  Creative industries minister Chris Bryant said Britain is in ‘active discussions’ with top US officials over Donald Trump’s mooted 100pc tariff on all films produced outside the US . Mr Bryant added that modern films are inherently ‘multinational’, citing Paddington in Peru being made in part by French Studio .  Emmanuel Macron said France intends to diversify its economic partners . French president also said there was a need for more public investments at a European Union level . He was speaking alongside new German Chancellor Friedrich Merz at the Elysee palace .  The Irish government expects the economy to expand 2.5pc this year, down from 2.9pc . It warned that in the event of a tariff war between the EU and US its growth would be 2pc . Ireland exported goods to the US worth €73bn (£61bn) last year, almost a third .  The dollar ticked up on Wednesday morning as investors factored in few surprises from today’s Federal Reserve meeting . The greenback gained ground against European currencies with the euro and pound down 0.1pc at $1.1366 .  Danish jeweller Pandora currently produces 95pc of its jewellery in Thailand . Donald Trump has threatened with 36pc import tariffs on the jewellery . The company hopes to open a plant in Vietnam next year - a country facing 46pc tariffs .  Australia’s film industry has pinned its hopes on actor Mel Gibson to convince Donald Trump to abandon his 100pc tariffs on films produced outside the US . US president hired the Braveheart actor in January as a “special ambassador” to Hollywood .  Mel Gibson's plans to shoot a film in Italy this year would bring home the impact of tariffs . The US president has mooted a 100pc tariff, saying Hollywood was dying a “very fast death” at the hand of incentives offered by foreign countries to lure filmmakers . BMW has said it expects to largely ride out the effect of sweeping US tariffs .  BMW’s South Carolina plant exported vehicles worth over $10bn (£7.5bn) last year . Around half of its US sales are imports from Europe, Mexico and South Africa . BMW said it expects ‘some of the tariff increases to be temporary, with reductions from July 2025’  PMI indicated construction firms are optimistic on balance about their prospects for the next 12 months despite the global economic turmoil . Goldman Sachs has predicted the US Federal Reserve will not cut interest rates until July .  The bank expects the US tariff rate on China to drop from around 160pc to around 60pc “relatively soon” with China likely to take similar action . However, Mr Hatzius said the outlook for interest rates “remains very uncertain”  Vietnam faces 46pc duties on its exports to the US if it is unable to reach an agreement with the White House at the end of a global 90-day tariff pause . Vietnam’s surplus with the US expanded by nearly 25pc in the four months to April year on year . In March alone, it exceeded $13.5bn, the highest monthly figure ever .  FTSE 100 at risk of breaking its record streak of gains despite trade talks between US and China . China announced earlier that Vice Premier He Lifeng will visit Switzerland from May 9 to 12 during which he will also have a meeting with a U.S. delegation .  Germany’s manufacturing demand rose by more than expected in March . Factory orders increased by 3.6pc compared to February, which was higher than expected . However, the figures will provide little solace for new chancellor Friedrich Merz as he prepares for the impact of US tariff policies .  The FTSE 100 closed just a single point higher on Tuesday, extending its record run of 16 consecutive days of gains by the skin of its teeth . Deal could come as soon as this week to soften the US president’s plans for 25pc tariffs on UK vehicles imported into the US .  Talks are the first opportunity for the two sides to de-escalate tensions after a protracted cat-and-mouse game over tariffs . The tensions have roiled global markets and upended supply chains . China’s stimulus package signalled a shift towards looser monetary policy in response to the trade shock .  Moscow and Beijing declared a “no limits partnership’ weeks before Putin ordered Russia’s Ukraine offensive in February 2022 . Xi hailed “resilient” China-Russia ties and called for other countries to stay out of their relationship . The Kremlin had praised Russia-China relations as a ‘genuine example’ of cooperation .  Jonathan Reynolds said he would not give a 'running commentary' on US trade deal . Business Secretary acknowledged there was ‘huge interest’ in reports that a UK-US trade deal would be signed imminently . Added his department was working “extremely hard across the board’s departments .  US and China will hold their first trade talks later this week since Donald Trump launched his tariff tirade . US treasury secretary Scott Bessent and chief trade negotiator Jamieson Greer will meet China’s economic tsar He Lifeng in Switzerland . Stock markets jumped in Asia and in after-hours trading in New York .  Donald Trump has imposed 145pc tariffs on imported goods from China, with Beijing hitting back with 125pc duties on American products . The two sides will meet in Switzerland later this week in a bid to de-escalate the tariff war .  U.S. treasury secretary Scott Bessent and chief trade negotiator Jamieson Greer to meet China’s economic tsar He Lifeng . Japan's Nikkei 225 gained 0.1pc to 36,870.46 .  China blue chips rose 0.2pc to 3,816.80. and Hong Kong’s Hang Seng . The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1pc to 40,829.00, the S&P 500 0.8pc, to 5,606.91, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.9pc to 17,689.66 .

Apple is considering embedding AI-powered search in Safari, report says . Apple services head Eddy Cuesaid the company is impressed by Perplexity AI's capabilities . Alternative partners under consideration include Anthropic, Claude chatbot creator and OpenAI .  Apple anticipates a deal to bring Google's Gemini AI to iPhones by midyear . With Apple exploring AI search options, the longstanding Google?Safari pact may be poised for a dramatic rewrite .

U.S. lawmakers warn Britain's order to Apple to create a backdoor to its encrypted user data could be exploited by cybercriminals and authoritarian regimes . Apple has said it would never build a so-called back door into its encrypted services or devices .  U.S.-UK agreement prohibits orders requiring companies to decrypt data . Under UK laws, American companies would commit a criminal offence if they disclose or confirm such an order, even to their home government . Lawmakers urge Cooper to allow Apple to disclose existence of the order to the US Department of Justice .  Individual's data to be accessed. individual's data should not be accessed, according to the government. individual data to the individual's individual's personal data to access.

Eddy Cue, Apple’s senior vice president of services, revealed that the company is “actively looking at” how to fold AI into its existing Safari browser . Cue foresees start-ups behind AI-generated search, like OpenAI, Perplexity AI Inc. and Anthropic PBC, will usurp traditional search tools such as Google or Bing .  Apple will add AI engines to its Safari browser in the future, Cue says . Talks between Apple and Perplexity are already underway, he disclosed . The DOJ’s lawsuit against Alphabet centers on an estimated $20 billion-a-year deal with Apple .  Apple’s revenue share from their agreement with Google remains the most financially appealing option, Cue said . Cue concluded that Google should remain the default search option .

Apple is considering reworking its Safari browser to place a greater emphasis on AI-powered search engines . Eddy Cue, Apple’s senior vice president of services, said he expects AI search providers to eventually replace Google . Apple has already seen a decline in Safari searches for the first time last month .  Currently, Apple and Alphabet have a lucrative agreement that allows Apple users to perform searches through Google . A shift away from Google and the entry of multiple competitors into the space could jeopardize that profitable arrangement .

Eddy Cue, Apple's services chief, hinted that AI-powered search engines like OpenAI, Perplexity, and Anthropic could eventually make their way onto Apple's browser . Cue acknowledged that AI search engines are gaining ground, saying, There's enough money now, enough large players, that I don't see how it doesn't happen. Apple has already integrated OpenAI's ChatGPT into Siri .  Cue admitted that Google still offers the best financial terms, but he emphasized that AI is a transformative wave that could open doors for new players . Expect more AI announcements at Apple's developer conference next month .

The Dow Jones Industrial Average is a benchmark index of the top 30 companies in the US . It represents the strength of the US economy and carries great historical significance . However, not all stocks within this elite group of companies perform equally . We decided to break down the index and find out the best and worst stocks .  The list is in ascending order, with the best stock taking the number one spot . Apple Inc. operates as a designer, manufacturer, and marketer of tablets, smartphones, wearables, personal computers, and accessories . The company’s stock is down 18% so far this year .  India now produces about 20% of Apple's iPhones, and the firm is planning to raise its iPhone production by 10% in India in 2025 . The firm tried to move its equipment to start iPhone 17 trial production, but the Chinese authorities blocked the transfer of equipment .  Overall, AAPLranks 3rdon our list of best and worst Dow stocks . While we acknowledge the potential of AAPL as an investment, our conviction lies in the belief that some AI stocks hold greater promise for delivering higher returns .

Shares of online advertising giant Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOGL) fell 8.2% in the afternoon session after Apple's top services chief, Eddy Cue, said the company was testing AI search tools like Perplexity for Safari . Cue clarified that Apple was not seeking to immediately end its partnership with Google as the default search engine on its devices .  Alphabet’s shares are extremely volatile and have had 35 moves greater than 2.5% over the last year . The previous big move we wrote about was 16 days ago when the stock dropped 3.2% .  Alphabet is down 20.1% since the beginning of the year, and at $151.37 per share, it is trading 26.7% below its 52-week high of $206.38 from February 2025 . Google Search, responsible for more than 50% of Alphabet's revenue, could be threatened . For the first time, searches on Safari (where Google Search is the default) declined, citing AI . Eddy Cue, Apple's senior vice president of services, testified Wednesday that Apple is "actively looking at" reshaping the Safari web browser .  The revelation came during Cue's testimony in the U.S. Justice Department's antitrust lawsuit against Alphabet . The deal that ensures Google is the default search engine in Apple's Safari browser is a key aspect in maintaining its dominance .  Google Search is responsible for more than half of Alphabet's total revenue . Losing its grip on internet searches would be very bad news for the company's bottom line . Alphabet's own AI offering is excellent, and I think it will ultimately weather this storm . Administration announced sweeping tariffs that led to significant market volatility and a sharp downturn in stock indices . Executives and experts in AI and data center construction have been worried about how trade levies would significantly increase the cost of constructing, equipping, and operating the data centers . We recently published a list of10 AI Stocks Getting Wall Street’s Attention Right Now .  What happens next to AI stocks largely depends on what’s next for tariffs . Strong companies, particularly the likes of Nvidia and Palantir, are likely to win over the longer term due to their smart innovations .  Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) is a technology company . Apple’s App Store revenues have demonstrated substantial growth with a notable rise in dollars per download . On May 6, the stock was revisited by a Wall Street analyst, Wamsi Mohan from Bank of America Securities, who maintained a “Buy” rating on the stock . Vietnam reaffirms its opening line on trade talks with Washington to avoid punishingly high tariffs . The Southeast Asian nation’s trade minister and top negotiator, Nguyen Hong Dien, urged firms to be “proactive” to help US-Vietnam trade reach its “great potential,” the government said .  Vietnam is among a group of countries opening trade talks with the US that are facing some of the steepest tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump . The surplus in April was $577 million, compared with the $1.64 billion reported for March . Vietnam is also a major trade partner for Vietnam but has challenged its access to offshore areas both countries claim in the South China Sea .  The US ran a nearly $124 billion trade deficit with Vietnam last year, the third-highest after China and Mexico . The surge in trading in recent years is partly due to firms leaving China to avoid Trump’s trade war during his first term . Vietnam has become a manufacturing base for multinational companies including Apple and Samsung .  The US normalized relations with Vietnam in 1995 after lifting a trade embargo the year before . Vietnam has previously sought to improve it export options to the US by applying for “market economy” status from Washington regulators . Critics argued the government in Hanoi controls prices and production and subsidizes enterprises that compete with American firms . Apple exec Eddy Cue testified in the U.S. Justice Department’s antitrust case against Alphabet . He said searches on Safari fell for the first time last month, which he attributed to users increasingly turning to AI-powered search engines . Google is the default search engine on Apple's Safari browser, earning $20 billion a year .  Apple's CEO says he believes AI search providers will eventually replace standard search engines such as Google . Last month, Google reassured jittery tech investors that its AI investments were powering returns at its crucial ad business .  If there are other viable alternatives for search, advertisers could move much of their ad budgets away from Google to these other venues . Google has a 90% share of ad revenue in the U.S.

Shares of Google parent Alphabet were down 9% in recent trading . Apple's senior vice president of services Eddy Cue reportedly said Apple is looking to add AI-powered search options to its Safari browser . Apple has reportedly held talks with Perplexity AI and ChatGPT maker OpenAI .  Google pays an estimated $20 billion a year to make its search engine the default option on Safari . Apple makes a cut of Google’s ad revenue from searches through the browser .

Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is quietly entering the AI coding assistant space . Anthropic is one of the most heavily funded artificial intelligence startups in the world . The tool will rely on Anthropic's Claude Sonnet, a cutting-edge AI-enhanced coding tool built into Xcode .  The assistant is designed to let Apple engineers build full software components using natural language . This marks one of Apple's first direct partnerships with a major AI player amid growing competition from Microsoft .  Claude Sonnet may replace Swift Assist behind the scenes as Apple ramps up internal AI infrastructure and evaluates the tool's long-term integration . Developers will be able to request bug fixes, test interface elements, or even write entire blocks of Swift code using natural language prompts .  Claude's Claude ecosystem is expanding rapidly across industries . Amazon leveraging Claude to power enterprise-level AWS offerings, Google collaborating on AI safety research, and Apple’s plans to integrate the tool into Xcode . According to Bloomberg, Apple remains cautious about a public rollout but sees strategic value in internal deployment .  Many are rushing to grab 4,000 of its pre-IPO shares for just $0.30/share! Amazon. partners with Amazon, Walmart & Target .

Apple's plans to add AI-powered search options to its Safari browser are a big blow to Google . The news slammed shares of Google-parent Alphabet, which closed down 7.3%, wiping off roughly $150 billion from its market value . Apple executive Eddy Cue said searches on Safari fell for the first time last month due to users increasingly turning to AI .  Google cited voice and visual search features as contributors to total search volume growth . It was unclear whether Cue was using the same basis of comparison in his testimony when analysing types of searches . Apple executive's comments suggest that a seismic shift in search is likely underway .  U.S. Justice Department has proposed to break up its dominance in online search . Google has reached into its deep pockets to fund its AI efforts and leverage its vast data trove .  Apple's Cue on Wednesday also said the company would add AI search providers, including OpenAI and Perplexity AI, as search options in the future . ChatGPT in April reported seeing over 1 billion weekly web searches for its search feature .  U.S. President Barack Obama was elected to the White House on Tuesday . The White House is expected to make the announcement at a later point .

Apple's senior vice president of services Eddy Cue revealed that Apple is exploring adding AI search engines such as Perplexity to its default Safari web browser . Cue's comments came during Google parent Alphabet's antitrust trial . Last year, a federal judge ruled that Google maintained an illegal monopoly through its search business .  Google has been working feverishly to ensure it catches up with AI startups like OpenAI and Perplexity . The company has already released its AI Overviews — generative AI-based responses to user queries — in standard Google Search . Google already provides an AI search competitor in the form of its Gemini search option .  Apple relies on Google's deal for revenue as part of its Services business . Services saw sales of $96.1 billion in 2024, making that $20 billion per year an important part of the segment . Apple stock ended the day roughly flat .

Apple's watch business took a hit last year, with volumes down 19% . Counterpoint Research says the main culprit is that the Series 10 didn't offer enough fresh features to excite buyers . Analyst Balbir Singh thinks Apple needs to shake things up in 2025 . He's calling for bold new features, refreshed SE and Ultra lines, and a possible design overhaul .  Smartwatches are a key growth lever for Apple's ecosystem . Losing ground in North America could hit revenue forecasts and investor confidence . Keep an eye on WWDC in June to see if Apple can reignite interest .

Prominent investor Bill Baruch says he has reduced his stakes in Nvidia, Broadcom, and Apple . Baruch cited several reasons for his moves, including speculation about tariffs being placed on semiconductors and downward pressure on AAPL's revenue .  Apple's revenue is "shrinking," while the tech giant's margins may drop due to tariffs . Baruch's exposure to Broadcom is double its weight in the S&P 500 . While we acknowledge the potential of NVDA, we believe AI stocks hold greater promise for delivering higher returns .

Gene Munster was asked on CNBC recently whether he was worried about the fate of Apple's revenue from Alphabet . Munster said the issue was one of the problems "that makes (him) not rest well at night" Munster is a longtime, well-known tech analyst at investment bank Piper Jaffray .  Munster remains largely Bullish on AAPL Stock . Munster expects AAPL "to prevail" against Epic Games . Pure Sweat Basketball, which offers basketball training online and through its apps, files lawsuit against Apple . Only 34 of an estimated 136,000 app developers in Apple’s App Store had applied to offer external payments via links as of May 2024 . Apple filed notice Monday that it will appeal U.S. District Court Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers’April 29 ruling .  Pure Sweat, based in Crystal Lake, Illinois, plans to modify its apps to include linked-out purchases on its own platforms . The new lawsuit closely mirrors Rogers’ latest ruling that described Apple’s actions . Apple also schemed to dissuade app users from clicking external payment links, Rogers said .  Law firm estimates ‘potentially more than 100,000’ app developers were unable to sell directly to customers . The suit alleges unjust enrichment, constructive trust and tortious interference with business . Hagens Berman Sobol Shapiro is seeking unspecified damages .

Artificial intelligence has been an epic catalyst for the likes of Nvidia and many of its big tech peers . Amazon has witnessed a near-trillion-dollar surge in its own valuation during the AI revolution . While Nvidia has a higher market cap than Amazon today, the e-commerce giant could leapfrog its semiconductor counterpart the end of the decade .  Amazon reports its revenue across six major categories: e-commerce, physical stores, third-party seller services, advertising, subscriptions, and Amazon Web Services . While AI has the potential to disrupt all of Amazon's operational segments, AWS and retail are the two that have me most encouraged . I think the company could be worth much more than semiconductor giant by next decade .  Amazon is outfitting its fulfillment centers with robotic processes that can bring a new level of automation and efficiency to packaging and shipping services . Amazon should be able to reduce labor costs over time, resulting in greater profitability for its core retail operation .  Amazon is in the early phases of developing its own AI chips . Microsoft, Meta Platforms, and Alphabetare pursuing similar ambitions . While I don't think this will be catastrophic for Nvidia, it likely won't help it in the long run . Investors might want to prepare for less robust growth in Nvidia's sales and profits .  Amazon appears to be in the early stages of taking advantage of new opportunities for accelerated growth . Amazon's valuation trends suggest that investors are not yet placing much of a premium at all on the company's efficiency improvements or long-run potential . Amazon should be in a position to continue accelerating sales while minting billions in cash flow in the process . Apple (AAPL) stock has bounced back impressively after last month’s tariff-driven sell-off sent it tumbling . With management radiating confidence and a hefty $100 billion buyback program in place, Apple's stock looks like a sturdy ship, even at its lofty price .  Apple's fiscal Q2 revenue was $95.4 billion, up 5% year-over-year, topping Wall Street's $94.68 billion forecast . iPhone sales came in strong at $46.8 billion, above the $45.6 billion expected . Mac revenue jumped 6.7% to $7.5 billion, fueled by the M4 MacBook Air . Services, the profit engine, soared 11.6% and set a new record .  Apple's Q2 profitability was a sight to behold . Net income rose to $24.8 billion and gross margins hit a stellar 46.9%, among the company's best ever . The secret sauce is a high-margin Services segment .  Apple expected gross margins to 45.5%-46.5% in Q3, below the 46.58% analysts hoped for . Cook noted years of supply chain diversification (half of U.S.-bound iPhones now from India, most Macs and iPads from Vietnam) cushion the blow .  At 28.5x this year’s expected EPS, Apple is no steal for a company growing in the mid-single digits . However, by leaning on domestic chip sourcing and a flexible supply chain alone, Apple has built a safeguard against trade wars that could sustain its growth . The $100 billion buyback program should continue to translate to elevated buying volumes for the stock .  Apple’s fiscal Q2 results demonstrate that the company is not just weathering tariff headwinds but is thriving despite them . With $95.4 billion in revenue, booming Services, and a supply chain dodging tariff blows, Apple's in fighting shape . The $100 billion buyback and unmatched ecosystem make it a solid buy, making me confident that Apple will keep shining .

Microsoft, Apple, and Nvidia have the most realistic chance of reaching the $4 trillion club first . Microsoft is racing to fill a $315 billion order backlog from customers who need more computing capacity for their artificial intelligence (AI) ambitions . Nvidia might be much further away from the mark, but it could legitimately achieve the milestone .  Since 2019, Microsoft invested around $14 billion in AI start-up OpenAI . Microsoft combined OpenAI's latest AI models with its own to create the Copilot virtual assistant . Copilot is now integrated into the company's flagship software products like Windows, Bing, and Edge, for free . It's available for subscribers of the 365 productivity suite for an additional monthly fee .  Microsoft said there were hundreds of thousands of organizations using Copilot for 365 around the world . CEO Satya Nadella said a record number of customers opted to buy more licenses during the quarter . The company rolled out new Copilot features to encourage more subscribers to upgrade .  Microsoft accounts for its AI cloud revenue under its Azure AI segment . Azure AI accounted for a record-high 16 percentage points (almost half) of that figure . The company opened new data centers in 10 countries in the third quarter alone .  Microsoft allocated $21.4 billion to capital expenditures (capex) during the third quarter, most of which went toward data center infrastructure . Microsoft is trading at a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 33.6 as of this writing . It's sitting roughly between Apple stock, which trades at a P/E ratio of 31.9 and Nvidia stock .  Microsoft is growing its EPS below trend at the moment, partly because of its enormous data center spending which is weighing on its profitability . According to Wall Street's consensus estimate, the company could increase its earnings by 12.8% in fiscal 2026 .  The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years . Apple cautioned investors that steep import tariffs will take a toll on profits beginning this quarter . iPhone sales remain lethargic, with last quarter’s measurable growth mostly rooted in unusual circumstances . Tariffs are arguably the least of Apple's problems right now, if you dig deeper into its historical results .  Apple turned $95.4 billion in revenue into earnings of $1.65 per share in fiscal Q3 . The iPhone accounted for roughly half of Apple's business, with sales of $46.8 billion . The company's services arm continues to shine as well .  iPhone unit sales of the iPhone improved 10% year over year, but that's a 10% improvement on a figure that fell by nearly as much in the comparable quarter a year earlier . Actual iPhone revenue remains more or less in line with where it peaked in 2022 .  The iPhone accounts for half of Apple's sales, and presumably, a comparable percentage of its profits . Without this push, it's conceivable that last quarter's iPhone business might have actually fallen . Apple didn't embrace this next generation of AI chatbots in earnest until last year .  Apple's AI chief has been removed as head of Siri's ongoing development . Tim Cook was forced to concede during the recent earnings call that the implementation of a new-and-improved Siri is "just taking a bit longer than we thought" Apple is usually isolationist, and such a decision confirms just how far behind its AI efforts .  Apple is steering customers to its competitors on AI-powered virtual assistants . Does this spell doom? Hardly . If nothing else, Apple remains the world's most profitable company .  The bottom line? Apple isn't necessarily a sell here . There's even a wobbly case for stepping into the stock while it's down more than 20% from its December peak . Apple's services business also remains impressive, even if it's not its flagship business .
